maml:description.maml:para: Displays basic information about Intel(R) Ethernet devices in the system.

The Get-IntelEthernet cmdlet displays basic information about the Intel(R) Ethernet devices present in the system, including the following: * Location on the PCI bus * Name * Link status * Connection name
By default, this cmdlet displays results as a table view. To view the results as a list, pipe the output to Format-List.
Specifies the name of an Intel Ethernet object.
Specifies a collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
A collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
A collection of Intel Ethernet objects.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernet

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays information for all Intel Ethernet devices in the system.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernet | Format-List

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays information for all Intel Ethernet devices in the system, as a list.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernet -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays information for an Intel Ethernet device with a specific name.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 4 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernet -Name "*E810*"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays information for all Intel Ethernet devices in the system from a specific device family, using wildcards.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 5 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters | Get-IntelEthernet

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays information for all Intel Ethernet devices stored in $Adapters.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 6 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernet -Adapter $Adapters[1]

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays information for the Intel Ethernet device stored in $Adapters[1].

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 7 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernet -Name $Adapters[1].ifDesc

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays information about the Intel Ethernet device stored in $Adapters[1], using its NetAdapter name (for example, Slot 5 Port 1).

maml:description.maml:para: Displays all the supported settings for Intel(R) Ethernet devices present in the system.
The Get-IntelEthernetSetting cmdlet displays all the supported settings for Intel(R) Ethernet devices present in the system.
By default, this cmdlet displays results as a table view. To view the results as a list, pipe the output to Format-List.
To view a description of a setting, append "| Select Minihelp" to the cmdlet syntax.
Specifies the name of an Intel Ethernet object.
Specifies a collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
Specifies the display name of an Intel Ethernet setting.
Specifies the registry keyword of an Intel Ethernet setting.
A collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
A collection of IntelEthernetSetting objects.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetSetting

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays the settings for all supported Intel Ethernet devices.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetSetting | Format-List

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays information for all Intel Ethernet settings as a list.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetSetting -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays settings for an Intel Ethernet device with a specific name.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 4 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters[1] | Get-IntelEthernetSetting

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets all of the settings supported on the device stored in $Adapters[1].

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 5 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetSetting -Name $Adapters[1].Name -DisplayName "Receive Side Scaling"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the Receive Side Scaling setting on the device stored in $Adapters[1] using the -Name parameter.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 6 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetSetting -RegistryKeyword "*RSS"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets all of the Receive Side Scaling settings on all the supported Ethernet devices in the system.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 7 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetSetting -RegistryKeyword "*RSS" | Select -Property Minihelp

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays the minihelp for the setting, for the indicated registry keyword.

maml:description.maml:para: Displays the settings and their values for the specified adapter and profile combination.

The Get-IntelEthernetProfileSetting cmdlet displays settings and their values for the specified Ethernet device and profile combination. The information is displayed in a table that shows the setting name and the value to which the setting will be changed.
Get-IntelEthernetProfileSetting returns a collection of setting objects.
Note: Use Set-IntelEthernetSetting to change an adapter to a specific profile.
Specifies the name of an Intel Ethernet object.
Specifies a collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.

Specifies the name of the profile. Possible profiles include the following:
* Standard Server - This profile is optimized for typical servers.
* Web Server - This profile is optimized for IIS and HTTP-based web servers.
* Virtualization Server (Hyper-V*) - This profile is optimized for Microsoft's Hyper-V virtualization environment. Requires Hyper-V for enablement.
* Storage Server - This profile is optimized for iSCSI over DCB performance. Selecting this profile will disable SR-IOV and VMQ. Requires Intel DCB for enablement.
* Storage + Virtualization - This profile is optimized for a combination of storage and virtualization requirements. Requires Intel DCB and Hyper-V for enablement.
* Low Latency - This profile is optimized to minimize network latency.
A collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
A collection of IntelEthernetSetting objects.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetProfileSetting -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Server Adapter E810-C-Q2" -ProfileName "Standard Server"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays the settings that would change, and the values they would change to, if you set the named Ethernet device to the specified profile.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetProfileSetting -Adapter $Adapters[1] -ProfileName "Standard Server"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays the settings that would change, and the values they would change to, if you set the Ethernet device stored in $Adapters[1] to the specified profile.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetProfileSetting -Adapter $Adapters[1] -ProfileName "Standard Server" PS C:\> Set-IntelEthernetSetting -Name $Adapters[1].Name -DisplayName "Profile" -DisplayValue "Standard Server"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Displays the settings that would change, and the values they would change to, if you set the Ethernet device stored in $Adapters[1] to the specified profile. Then changes the adapter's profile setting to Standard Server.

maml:description.maml:para: Configures settings for Intel(R) Ethernet devices.
The Set-IntelEthernetSetting cmdlet configures settings for Intel(R) Ethernet devices.
By default, this cmdlet displays results as a table view. To view the results as a list, pipe the output to Format-List.
Specifies the name of the Intel Ethernet device.
Specifies a collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
Specifies the registry keyword of an Intel Ethernet setting.
Specifies the registry value of an Intel Ethernet setting.
Specifies the display name of an Intel Ethernet setting.
Specifies the display value of an Intel Ethernet setting.
Specifies the collection of IntelEthernetSetting objects where DisplayValue or RegistryValue will be modified.
Resets the setting to its the default value.
A collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
A collection of IntelEthernetSetting objects.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-IntelEthernetSetting -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2" -RegistryKeyword "*RSS" -RegistryValue "1"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Enables the *RSS registry keyword setting for an Intel Ethernet device with a specific name.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Set-IntelEthernetSetting -Adapter $Adapters[1] -DisplayName "Receive Side Scaling" -DisplayValue "Disabled" | Format-List

dev:remarks.maml:para: Disables the Receive Side Scaling setting on the device stored in $Adapters[1] and formats the output as a list.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $RSS = Get-IntelEthernetSetting -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2" -RegistryKeyword "*RSS" PS C:\> Set-IntelEthernetSetting -Setting $RSS -Reset

dev:remarks.maml:para: Resets the *RSS setting on a specific device to its default value.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 4 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters[1] | Set-IntelEthernetSetting -RegistryKeyword "*RSS" -RegistryValue 1

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the *RSS setting to 1 (Enabled).

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 5 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $RSS = Get-IntelEthernetSetting -DisplayName "Receive Side Scaling" PS C:\> $RSS | Set-IntelEthernetSetting -DisplayValue "Disabled"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Disables the indicated setting, using an IntelEthernetSetting object and the display value.

maml:description.maml:para: Blinks the LED on the specified port of an Intel(R) Ethernet device for a defined number of seconds.

The Invoke-IntelEthernetIdentifyPort cmdlet blinks the LED on the specified port of an Intel(R) Ethernet device for the number of seconds specified by the -Seconds parameter. NOTE: Backplane devices do not support this test.
Specifies the name of the Intel Ethernet device.
Specifies a collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
Specifies the number of seconds to blink the LED, from 1 to 120 seconds.
An Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) object.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Invoke-IntelEthernetIdentifyPort -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2" -Seconds 45

dev:remarks.maml:para: Blinks the LED on the port of a specific device for 45 seconds.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Invoke-IntelEthernetIdentifyPort -Adapter $Adapters[1] -Seconds 45

dev:remarks.maml:para: Blinks the LED on the port of the device stored in $Adapters[1] for 45 seconds.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapter = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Invoke-IntelEthernetIdentifyPort $Adapter[1] -Seconds 90

dev:remarks.maml:para: Blinks the LED on the port of the device stored in $Adapter[1] for 90 seconds.

maml:description.maml:para: Runs hardware diagnostic tests on the specified adapter(s).

The Test-IntelEthernetHardware cmdlet runs hardware tests on the specified adapter and displays the results. Displays the results of the test in a list view. Note: Not all devices support every hardware test.
Specifies a collection of adapter objects on which to run hardware tests.
Specifies the name of the network adapter on which to run hardware tests.
Specifies a collection of adapter objects on which to run hardware tests.
Specifies the name of the network adapter on which to run hardware tests.
A collection of adapter objects returned from the cmdlet Get-IntelEthernet.
A collection of results from the hardware tests.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Test-IntelEthernetHardware -Adapter $Adapters[1]

dev:remarks.maml:para: Runs the hardware tests on the adapter stored in $Adapters[1].

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Test-IntelEthernetHardware -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet 25G 2P E810-XXV Adapter"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Runs hardware tests on the Intel(R) Ethernet 25G 2P E810-XXV Adapter.

maml:description.maml:para: Outputs Data Center Bridging Status debug information for the specified adapter.

Displays a snapshot of the Data Center Bridging Status debug information for the specified adapter formatted for output to a file. NOTE: For a detailed explanation of the cmdlet's output, see readme.txt.
Specifies the name of the Intel Ethernet device.
Specifies a collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
An Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) object.

dev:type.maml:name: A snapshot of the input device's DCB state formatted for file output.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetDCBStatus

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the DCB state of every supported Intel Ethernet device

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Name "*E810*"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the DCB state for all supported Intel Ethernet E810 Series devices in the system using a wildcard.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters | Get-IntelEthernetDCBStatus

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the DCB state information for all the Intel Ethernet devices stored in $Adapters that support the cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Allows you to display the configuration of logs for supported categories of events on Intel(R) Ethernet devices.

The Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig cmdlet retrieves the configuration of logs for supported categories (called "modules") of events on Intel(R) Ethernet devices. By default, this cmdlet displays all devices, their supported modules, and the accompanying log level, per module, as a table view. To view the results as a list, pipe the output to Format-List.
For the Driver module, you can use the -SubModule parameter to retrieve the driver logs for specific subcategories.
Use the Set-IntelEthernetLogConfig, Disable-IntelEthernetLogConfig, and Reset-IntelEthernetLogConfig cmdlets to change the configuration of the driver logs.
Specifies the name of the network device.
Specifies a collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.

Specifies the module to get configuration for. Note: You cannot specify both the -Module and -Configuration parameters. Use the Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig cmdlet to display a list of supported modules.
Specifies a configuration for a group of modules. Note: You cannot specify both the -Module and -Configuration parameters.
Valid values for Configuration are: * AQ Interface * Diagnostics * Infrastructure * Initialization * IO * Link Management * Manageability * NVM * Protocols * QoS * RX * TimeSync * TX * XLR
Specifies the submodules to retrieve when the Module parameter includes Driver. Note: You can only use the -SubModule parameter when -Module is set to Driver.
The parameter accepts both symbolic and numeric values as input (for example, 1, 0x1, or "Default" are all acceptable parameter values).
The parameter accepts a summed numeric value of more than one submodule (such as 0x3f, which would enable "Default" through "FuncCall" submodules).
If you do not provide -SubModule with the Driver module, it uses a default summed value of 0x3f (enabling the "Default" through "FuncCall" submodules).

Valid symbolic and number values for SubModule are: Default = 0x1 Init = 0x2 Resource = 0x4 Request = 0x8 Power = 0x10 FuncCall = 0x20 Shared = 0x40 Link = 0x80 Offload = 0x100 Tx = 0x200 Rx = 0x400 Packet = 0x800 Interrupt = 0x1000 Lock = 0x2000 Watchdog = 0x4000 SIPS = 0x8000 RCTL = 0x10000 RDMA = 0x20000 RDMA_Shared = 0x40000 RDMA_CM = 0x80000 RDMA_Resources = 0x100000 Diagnostics = 0x200000
A collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
A collection of log configuration objects.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the log configuration information for all Intel(R) Ethernet devices in the system that support firmware logging.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig | Format-List

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the log configuration information for all Intel Ethernet devices that support firmware logging and displays the results as a list.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Name "*E810*"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the log configuration information for all supported Intel Ethernet E810 Series devices in the system using a wildcard.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 4 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2" -Module "NVM"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the log configuration information for the NVM module, for a device with a specific name.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 5 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters | Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the log configuration information for all the Intel Ethernet devices stored in $Adapters that support firmware logging.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 6 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Adapter $Adapters[1] -Module "NVM","ACL"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the log configuration information for the device stored in $Adapters[1], for the NVM and ACL modules.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 7 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters | Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Configuration "NVM","Initialization"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the log configuration information for Intel Ethernet devices stored in $Adapters, for the modules that are part of the NVM and Initialization configuration group.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 8 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Name "*E810*" -Configuration "In*"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the log configuration information for all supported Intel Ethernet E810 Series devices in the system using a wildcard, for all configuration groups that begin with the letters "In." In this case, it would get information about the Infrastructure and Initialization configuration groups.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 9 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2" -Module "Driver" -SubModule "0xFF00"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the log configuration information for the Driver module from the submodules "Offload" through "SIPS", for a device with a specific name.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the log configuration for supported categories of events on Intel(R) Ethernet adapters.

The Set-IntelEthernetLogConfig cmdlet allows you to set the level for log messages for supported categories (called "modules") of events on Intel(R) Ethernet adapters. You can set the verbosity level of individual modules or for supported groups of modules. To view the results as a list, pipe the output to Format-List.
For the Driver module, you can use the -SubModule parameter to configure driver logs for specific subcategories.
Use the Disable-IntelEthernetLogConfig cmdlet to disable logging for all modules. Use the Reset-IntelEthernetLogConfig cmdlet to reset all modules for a device to the driver's default log levels.
Specifies the name of the network device.
Specifies a collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.

Specifies the module to set configuration for. Note: You cannot specify both the -Module and -Configuration parameters. Use the Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig cmdlet to display a list of supported modules.
Specifies the log level to set configuration for.
For the Driver module, the only valid values are Normal or Verbose.
Valid Level values for all other modules are: * Disabled * Error * Warning * Normal * Verbose
Specifies a configuration for a group of modules. Note: You cannot specify both the -Module and -Configuration parameters.
Valid values for Configuration are: * AQ Interface * Diagnostics * Infrastructure * Initialization * IO * Link Management * Manageability * NVM * Protocols * QoS * RX * TimeSync * TX * XLR
Specifies the submodules that are enabled when the Module parameter includes Driver. Note: You can only use the -SubModule parameter when -Module is set to Driver.
The parameter accepts both symbolic and numeric values as input (for example, 1, 0x1, or "Default" are all acceptable parameter values).
The parameter accepts a summed numeric value of more than one submodule (such as 0x3f, which would enable "Default" through "FuncCall" submodules).
If you do not provide -SubModule with the Driver module, it uses a default summed value of 0x3f (enabling the "Default" through "FuncCall" submodules).

Valid symbolic and number values for SubModule are: Default = 0x1 Init = 0x2 Resource = 0x4 Request = 0x8 Power = 0x10 FuncCall = 0x20 Shared = 0x40 Link = 0x80 Offload = 0x100 Tx = 0x200 Rx = 0x400 Packet = 0x800 Interrupt = 0x1000 Lock = 0x2000 Watchdog = 0x4000 SIPS = 0x8000 RCTL = 0x10000 RDMA = 0x20000 RDMA_Shared = 0x40000 RDMA_CM = 0x80000 RDMA_Resources = 0x100000 Diagnostics = 0x200000
A collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
If successful, the cmdlet returns a collection of modules and level objects.
In the case of failure, the cmdlet returns a failure message.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Name "*E810*" -Module "NVM" -Level "Verbose"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the log's configuration level to Verbose for the NVM module, for all Intel(R) Ethernet E810 Series devices in the system using a wildcard.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2" -Module "Switch" -Level "Warning"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the configuration to log warning messages for the Switch module, for a device with a specific name.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters | Set-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Module "MDIO" -Level "Error"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the configuration to log error messages for the MDIO module, for all the devices stored in $Adapters.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 4 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Name "*E810*" -Configuration "Link Management" -Level "Error"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the configuration to log error messages for the Link Management configuration group, for all Intel Ethernet E810 Series devices in the system using a wildcard.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 5 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters | Set-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Configuration "NVM","Initialization" -Level "Warning"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the configuration to log warning messages for Intel Ethernet devices stored in $Adapters, for the modules that are part of the NVM and Initialization configuration groups.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 6 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters | Set-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Module "Driver" -SubModule "0x4000" -Level "Verbose"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the configuration to log only verbose level watchdog-related Driver module messages, for all the devices stored in $Adapters.

maml:description.maml:para: Starts collecting driver logs for Intel(R) Ethernet devices that support firmware logging.

The Start-IntelEthernetLog cmdlet starts collecting driver logs for Intel(R) Ethernet devices that support firmware logging. By default, the cmdlet saves the log file to a default location (in C:\%LOCALAPPDATA%\Local\Intel\Wired Networking). You can specify a different file path and log name using the -Path parameter.
Use the Stop-IntelEthernetLog cmdlet to stop collecting the driver log.

Use the Get-IntelEthernetLogConfig cmdlet to view the configuration of the driver logs. Use the Set-IntelEthernetLogConfig, Disable-IntelEthernetLogConfig, and Reset-IntelEthernetLogConfig cmdlets to change the configuration of the driver logs.
Specifies the name of the network device.
Specifies an Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) object.
Specifies the path and filename for logs to be written to.
Overwrites the log file with a new one, if it already exists.
Appends information to the log file, if it already exists.
An Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) object.
If successful, it lists the path of the log file. In the case of failure, the cmdlet returns a failure message.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Start-IntelEthernetLog -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Starts logging for the device with the specified name.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Start-IntelEthernetLog -Adapter $Adapters[1]

dev:remarks.maml:para: Starts logging for the device stored in $Adapters[1] and saves the log to the default location.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Start-IntelEthernetLog -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2" -Force

dev:remarks.maml:para: Starts logging for the device with the specified name and overwrites the previous log file saved at the default location.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 4 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Start-IntelEthernetLog -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2" -Path "C:\E810_Log"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Starts logging for the specified device and saves a log file at C:\E810_Log.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 5 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Start-IntelEthernetLog -Adapter $Adapters[1] -Force

dev:remarks.maml:para: Starts logging for the device stored in $Adapters[1] and overwrites the previous log file saved at the default location.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 6 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Start-IntelEthernetLog -Adapter $Adapters[1] -Append

dev:remarks.maml:para: Starts logging for the device stored in $Adapters[1] and appends it to a previous log file saved at the default location.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 7 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Start-IntelEthernetLog -Adapter $Adapters[1] -Path "C:\E810_Log" -Append

dev:remarks.maml:para: Starts logging for the device stored in $Adapters[1] and appends it to the existing log file at C:\E810_Log.

maml:description.maml:para: Stops the driver log started by the Start-IntelEthernetLog cmdlet.
The Stop-IntelEthernetLog cmdlet stops the driver log started by the Start-IntelEthernetLog cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the network device.
Specifies an Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) object.
An Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) object.
If successful, no message is returned. In the case of failure, the cmdlet returns a failure message.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Stop-IntelEthernetLog

dev:remarks.maml:para: Stops logging for devices started with Start-IntelEthernetLog.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Stop-IntelEthernetLog -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Stops logging started with Start-IntelEthernetLog for the specified device.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Stop-IntelEthernetLog -Adapter $Adapters[1]

dev:remarks.maml:para: Stops logging for the device stored in $Adapters[1].

maml:description.maml:para: Disables driver logging for all categories of events on supported Intel(R) Ethernet devices.

The Disable-IntelEthernetLogConfig cmdlet disables driver logging for all categories of events on supported Intel(R) Ethernet devices, by setting log levels to Disabled. By default, this cmdlet displays its output as a table, grouped by device. To view the results as a list, pipe the output to Format-List.
Specifies the name of the network device.
Specifies a collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
A collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
A collection of log configuration objects.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Disable-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Name "*E810*"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the log's configuration level to Disabled for all Intel(R) Ethernet E810 Series devices in the system using a wildcard.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Disable-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the log's configuration level to Disabled for a device with a specific name.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters | Disable-IntelEthernetLogConfig

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the log's configuration to Disabled, for all the devices stored in $Adapters.

maml:description.maml:para: Resets all modules for a device to the driver's default log levels.

The Reset-IntelEthernetLogConfig cmdlet resets all modules for a device to the driver's default log levels, for Intel Ethernet(R) devices that support logging. By default, this cmdlet displays its output as a table, grouped by device. To view the results as a list, pipe the output to Format-List.
Specifies the name of the network device.
Specifies a collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
A collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
A collection of log configuration objects.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Reset-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Name "*E810*"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Resets the log configuration levels for all Intel(R) Ethernet E810 Series devices in the system using a wildcard.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Reset-IntelEthernetLogConfig -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Resets the log configuration levels for a device with a specific name.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters | Reset-IntelEthernetLogConfig

dev:remarks.maml:para: Resets the log configuration levels, for all the Intel Ethernet devices stored in $Adapters that support logging.

maml:description.maml:para: Writes the results of a debug dump to a file, for a supported Intel(R) Ethernet device.

On supported Intel(R) Ethernet devices, the Write-IntelEthernetDebugDump cmdlet obtains runtime register values from the firmware and then writes the results to a single dump file, for debugging complicated issues in the field. This debug dump contains a snapshot of the device and its existing hardware configuration, such as switch tables, transmit scheduler tables, and other information.
NOTE: The contents of the debug dump are not human-readable. You must work with Customer Support to decode the file.
This feature is supported only on Intel(R) Ethernet 810 Series devices.
Specifies the name of the network device.
Specifies an Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) object.
Specifies clusters to dump existing hardware configuration information. Dumps all clusters by default.
Valid values for Cluster are: * Switch * ACL * Tx Scheduler * Profile Configuration * Link * DCB * L2P * Manageability Transactions
Specifies the path and filename for the dump file to be written to.
Overwrites the dump file with a new one, if it already exists.
Appends information to the dump file, if it already exists.
Specifies an Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) object.
If successful, the cmdlet returns the path of the debug dump file. In the case of failure, the cmdlet returns a failure message.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Write-IntelEthernetDebugDump -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Dumps all cluster information for the specified device and writes it to the default location.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Write-IntelEthernetDebugDump -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2" -Cluster "Link"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Dumps the Link cluster information for the specified device and writes it to the default location.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters[1] | Write-IntelEthernetDebugDump -Cluster "Link"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Dumps the Link cluster information for the device stored in $Adapters[1] and writes it to the default location.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 4 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Write-IntelEthernetDebugDump -Adapter $Adapters[1] -Cluster "Link" -Append

dev:remarks.maml:para: Dumps the Link cluster information for the device stored in $Adapters[1] and appends it to a previous file saved at the default location.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 5 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Write-IntelEthernetDebugDump -Adapter $Adapters[1] -Cluster "Link" -Path "C:\E810_Dump" -Append

dev:remarks.maml:para: Dumps the Link cluster information for the device stored in $Adapters[1] and appends it to the existing file at C:\E810_Dump.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 6 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Write-IntelEthernetDebugDump -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2" -Cluster "Link" -Force

dev:remarks.maml:para: Dumps the debug information for the Link cluster for the device with the specified name and overwrites the previous file saved at the default location.

maml:description.maml:para: Registers the RDMA statistics counters with perfmon.
The Register-IntelEthernetRDMACounterSet cmdlet registers the RDMA statistics counters for the specific device with perfmon.
You can use this cmdlet to re-register the counters.
Specifies the name of an Intel Ethernet object.
Specifies a collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
A collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Register-IntelEthernetRDMACounterSet

dev:remarks.maml:para: Registers the RDMA statistics counters for all supported Intel Ethernet devices.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Register-IntelEthernetRDMACounterSet -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Registers the RDMA statistics counters for the specified Intel Ethernet device.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Register-IntelEthernetRDMACounterSet -Name "*E810*"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Registers the RDMA statistics counters for all Intel Ethernet devices in the system from a specific device family, using wildcards.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 4 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters | Register-IntelEthernetRDMACounterSet

dev:remarks.maml:para: Registers the RDMA statistics counters for all Intel Ethernet devices stored in $Adapters.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 5 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Register-IntelEthernetRDMACounterSet -Adapter $Adapters[1]

dev:remarks.maml:para: Registers the RDMA statistics counters for the Intel Ethernet device stored in $Adapters[1].

maml:description.maml:para: Unregisters the RDMA statistics counters from perfmon.
The Unregister-IntelEthernetRDMACounterSet cmdlet unregisters the RDMA statistics counters for the specified device from perfmon.
Specifies the name of an Intel Ethernet object.
Specifies a collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.
A collection of Intel (IntelEthernetAdapter or IANet_PhysicalEthernetAdapter) or Microsoft (MSFT_NetAdapter or Win32_NetworkAdapter) objects.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Unregister-IntelEthernetRDMACounterSet

dev:remarks.maml:para: Unregisters the RDMA statistics counters for all supported Intel Ethernet devices.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Unregister-IntelEthernetRDMACounterSet -Name "Intel(R) Ethernet Network Adapter E810-C-Q2"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Unregisters the RDMA statistics counters for the specified Intel Ethernet device.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 3 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Unregister-IntelEthernetRDMACounterSet -Name "*E810*"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Unregisters the RDMA statistics counters for all Intel Ethernet devices in the system from a specific device family, using wildcards.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 4 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> $Adapters | Unregister-IntelEthernetRDMACounterSet

dev:remarks.maml:para: Unregisters the RDMA statistics counters for all Intel Ethernet devices stored in $Adapters.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ EXAMPLE 5 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Adapters = Get-IntelEthernet PS C:\> Unregister-IntelEthernetRDMACounterSet -Adapter $Adapters[1]

dev:remarks.maml:para: Unregisters the RDMA statistics counters for the Intel Ethernet device stored in $Adapters[1].
